Marie Curie: Marie Curie, a Polish-French physicist and chemist, made groundbreaking discoveries in radioactivity. I would bring her back to life to discuss her research, the ethical implications of her discoveries, and how her work has shaped our understanding of the universe.

Leonardo da Vinci: Leonardo da Vinci, an Italian polymath, was a master of art, science, and technology. I would bring him back to life to gain insights into his creative process, learn about his inventions, and discuss the intersection of art and science.

Eleanor Roosevelt: Eleanor Roosevelt, an American politician and social reformer, was a key figure in the American political landscape. I would bring her back to life to discuss her advocacy for civil rights, her role in the United Nations, and her impact on American history.

Gandhi: Mahatma Gandhi, an Indian independence activist, used nonviolent resistance to bring about significant social and political change. I would bring him back to life to discuss his philosophy, his leadership style, and the impact of his actions on India's independence and the world.

Jane Austen: Jane Austen, an English novelist, wrote classic works that explore the complexities of human relationships. I would bring her back to life to discuss her writing, her observations on society, and the enduring appeal of her stories.
